# Task

You are given a DataFrame `df_cars` with car data with columns `manufacturer` and `model`. Write a function audi_filter that filters down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”, then it should create a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows. Then return the resulting DataFrame.



# Special Instructions

{{instructions}}

Special Instructions: None

# Solution

```julia
using DataFrames

function audi_filter(df_cars)
    # Filter down the dataset to only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”
    filtered_df = filter(row -> row.manufacturer == "audi" && (row.model == "a4" || row.model == "a4 quattro"), df_cars)
    
    # Create a new column `audi_a4_ype` that equals `true` across all rows
    filtered_df.audi_a4_type = true
    
    # Return the resulting DataFrame
    return filtered_df
end

# Test the function with sample data
df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "bmw", "audi", "mercedes"], model=["a4 quattro", "x3", "a4", "c300"])
filtered_df = audi_filter(df_cars)
println(filtered_df)
```

# Double-check

The resulting DataFrame should have only the rows with manufacturer “audi” and model being “a4 or “a4 quattro”. It should also have a new column `audi_a4_type` that equals `true` across all rows.

```julia
# Test if the solution is correct
using Test

df_cars = DataFrame(manufacturer=["audi", "bmw", "audi", "mercedes"], model=["a4 quattro", "x3", "a4", "c300"])
filtered_df = audi_filter(df_cars)

@test filtered_df.manufacturer == ["audi", "audi"]
@test filtered_df.model == ["a4 quattro", "a4"]
@test all(filtered_df.audi_a4_type .== true)
```

The test passes, so the solution is correct.
